elements.content: The photo-active MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), despite having a very similar crystalline structure, exhibit different optical behaviors. Luminescence in MIL-125 decays in about 1 ns, while for its amino counterpart, the lifetime of charge carriers is at least 1 order of magnitude larger. The origin of this difference is the key element for understanding the photocatalytic behavior of MIL-125-NH2 when associated with active nanoparticles, a behavior that is completely absent in MIL-125. By performing advanced ab initio electronic structure calculations, we find that charge carriers interact differently in the two MOFs with subsequent effects on the luminescence lifetimes and their catalytic performances. To confirm the predictions of our model, we synthesized a novel material in the MIL-125 family, MIL-125-NH2-[10%]­(OH)2, and confirm that our theory correctly predicts a faster decay compared to MIL-125-NH2.
elements.clean_text: The photo-active MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), despite having a very similar crystalline structure, exhibit different optical behaviors. Luminescence in MIL-125 decays in about 1 ns, while for its amino counterpart, the lifetime of charge carriers is at least 1 order of magnitude larger. The origin of this difference is the key element for understanding the photocatalytic behavior of MIL-125-NH2 when associated with active nanoparticles, a behavior that is completely absent in MIL-125. By performing advanced ab initio electronic structure calculations, we find that charge carriers interact differently in the two MOFs with subsequent effects on the luminescence lifetimes and their catalytic performances. To confirm the predictions of our model, we synthesized a novel material in the MIL-125 family, MIL-125-NH2-[10%](OH)2, and confirm that our theory correctly predicts a faster decay compared to MIL-125-NH2.

elements.content: Photo-induced hydrogen water splitting is a promising alternative to standard electrolysis techniques. The photocatalytic production of hydrogen proceeds following three steps: (i) sunlight absorption and generation of charge carriers (electrons, e–, and holes, h+), (ii) migration of the charge carriers to the catalytic active sites, and (iii) reduction reaction of water with subsequent H2 production and parallel oxidation reaction in order to neutralize the remaining negative charge of the photogenerated electron. In this context, large efforts have been devoted to the search for the ideal photocatalyst material. Among them, metal–organic-frameworks (MOFs) have attracted the attention of a growing scientific community because of their possible application in an expanding range of fields.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Photo-induced hydrogen water splitting is a promising alternative to standard electrolysis techniques. The photocatalytic production of hydrogen proceeds following three steps: (i) sunlight absorption and generation of charge carriers (electrons, e-, and holes, h+), (ii) migration of the charge carriers to the catalytic active sites, and (iii) reduction reaction of water with subsequent H2 production and parallel oxidation reaction in order to neutralize the remaining negative charge of the photogenerated electron. In this context, large efforts have been devoted to the search for the ideal photocatalyst material. Among them, metal-organic-frameworks (MOFs) have attracted the attention of a growing scientific community because of their possible application in an expanding range of fields.

elements.content: MOFs are crystalline materials, formed by organic molecules, the linkers, connected by inorganic metal-oxide nodes. Their modular structure allows us to study singular components, and their interactions can improve their chemical–physical performances. In the field of photoinduced catalysis, many studies have been carried out in this direction.
elements.clean_text: MOFs are crystalline materials, formed by organic molecules, the linkers, connected by inorganic metal-oxide nodes. Their modular structure allows us to study singular components, and their interactions can improve their chemical-physical performances. In the field of photoinduced catalysis, many studies have been carried out in this direction.

elements.content: In this context, a photoactive MOF absorbs photons, and then photogenerated electrons are injected into a catalytic nanoparticle (NP). The water reduction reaction occurs on the surface of the NPs, while the hole is captured using a hole scavenger dissolved into the solution. This composite MOF/metallic NPs, MOF/NP system, detains the current record of molar hydrogen production under solar illumination. In this system, the MOF, MIL-125-NH2 (MIL = Materials of Institute Lavoisier), acts as the antenna and the catalyst is phosphorus oxide NPs.
elements.clean_text: In this context, a photoactive MOF absorbs photons, and then photogenerated electrons are injected into a catalytic nanoparticle (NP). The water reduction reaction occurs on the surface of the NPs, while the hole is captured using a hole scavenger dissolved into the solution. This composite MOF/metallic NPs, MOF/NP system, detains the current record of molar hydrogen production under solar illumination. In this system, the MOF, MIL-125-NH2 (MIL = Materials of Institute Lavoisier), acts as the antenna and the catalyst is phosphorus oxide NPs.

elements.content: MIL-125 is formed by cyclic octamers of TiO2 octahedra linked by 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) (). The substitution of the linker with the mono-aminated bdc-NH2 forms the MOF, MIL-125-NH2, used in the composite system. Interestingly, this chemical modification appears to be quintessential for the efficiency of the photocatalytic process. In fact, the de-aminated MIL-125, while possessing a very similar crystalline structure, is not able to produce any hydrogen. This might be correlated to a different electronic and optical behavior. Indeed, recent experiments have pointed out that the amino group is able to stabilize the hole leading to an efficient charge separation of the photo-excited electron and hole, a stabilization that is missing for the de-aminated MIL-125. In addition, the lifetime of the charge carriers is at least 1 order of magnitude larger in MIL-125-NH2 than in MIL-125 (about 1 ns). These fascinating results show that an apparently small chemical modification of the linker might have a large impact on the electronic and optical properties of a material, then making an essential difference in its technical performances.

elements.content: From a practical point of view, these results can have significant importance allowing us to enhance specific properties, in this case charge separation, by simply operating a chemical substitution. To fully exploit the potential of such a chemical modification, it is desirable to have a detailed molecular understanding of this behavior. Such an understanding would hopefully avoid an elaborate trial and error to identify an optimal linker.
elements.clean_text: From a practical point of view, these results can have significant importance allowing us to enhance specific properties, in this case charge separation, by simply operating a chemical substitution. To fully exploit the potential of such a chemical modification, it is desirable to have a detailed molecular understanding of this behavior. elements.content: A large number of high-throughput studies have been deployed to perform computational screenings aimed at fine-tuning the opto-electronic properties of MOFs. These studies have focussed on the effect of linker functionalization on the structural and electronic properties of MOFs and have received a profound attention, in particular, theoretical studies have shown that the band gap of MIL-125 can be tuned by adding different functional groups to bdc. The main drawback of most studies is the use of computational protocols featuring an approximated treatment of the electronic structure, which may only give qualitative results. Furthermore, thermal effects on the electronic structure are usually neglected, an approximation that might provide another possible source of errors.
elements.clean_text: A large number of high-throughput studies have been deployed to perform computational screenings aimed at fine-tuning the opto-electronic properties of MOFs. These studies have focussed on the effect of linker functionalization on the structural and electronic properties of MOFs and have received a profound attention, in particular, theoretical studies have shown that the band gap of MIL-125 can be tuned by adding different functional groups to bdc. The main drawback of most studies is the use of computational protocols featuring an approximated treatment of the electronic structure, which may only give qualitative results. Furthermore, thermal effects on the electronic structure are usually neglected, an approximation that might provide another possible source of errors.

elements.content: Overall, although previous studies provide important qualitative information, the use of approximated methods prevents achieving a comprehensive explanation regarding the effects of chemical modifications on the opto-electronic properties of this class of MOFs. In addition, at present, we do not even have a qualitative theoretical understanding why the lifetimes of the electron/hole pair that is formed after photo excitation in these materials are so different. In this context, the approximated methods commonly employed would provide an incorrect description of charge localization and its energetics because of the self-interaction error affecting semilocal density functionals but also hybrid functionals, if the fraction of Fock exchange is not correctly determined (e.g., ref ). Therefore, the current lack of in-depth studies prevents the opto-electronic properties of MOFs and their correlation with the chemical modifications from being completely understood.

elements.content: In this work, we develop a theoretical framework to qualitatively predict the effects of the functionalization of the ligand on the electronic and optical properties of MOFs. As a particular example, we aim to obtain a detailed molecular understanding why the electronic and optical properties of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 are so different. The electronic and optical properties of MIL-based MOFs are still far from being completely understood, and their correlation with the chemical modifications has not been rationalized yet. Theoretical studies have shown that the band gap of MIL-125 can be tuned by adding different functional groups to bdc. However, although these studies provide important qualitative information, the conventional methods use approximated methods which are not capable of explaining these drastic effects of chemical modifications on the opto-electronic properties of this class of MOFs. In addition, at present, we do not even have a theoretical understanding why the lifetimes of the electron/hole pair that is formed after photo excitation in these materials are so different.

However, although these studies provide important qualitative information, the conventional methods use approximated methods which are not capable of explaining these drastic effects of chemical modifications on the opto-electronic properties of this class of MOFs. In addition, at present, we do not even have a theoretical understanding why the lifetimes of the electron/hole pair that is formed after photo excitation in these materials are so different.

elements.content: We calculate the electronic structure of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 using advanced hybrid functional calculations. To ensure that calculations of the frontier orbitals, or in band-structure terms, the top of the valence band (VB) and the bottom of the conduction band (CB), are not biased by the self-interaction error, we derive the amount of Fock exchange to be included in the PBE0 functional from physical considerations based on the Koopman’s condition. The challenges in correctly describing the fundamental energy gap of MOFs, without such a bias-free methodology, have been discussed by several authors. In fact, very often, the only experimental information that is provided is the optical gap that has a very different nature from the fundamental one, making it even harder to compare energy levels and experiments. Our method provides us with a direct determination of Fock exchange that allows us to compute the optical gap in striking agreement with the experimental one reported previously.
elements.clean_text: We calculate the electronic structure of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 using advanced hybrid functional calculations. To ensure that calculations of the frontier orbitals, or in band-structure terms, the top of the valence band (VB) and the bottom of the conduction band (CB), are not biased by the self-interaction error, we derive the amount of Fock exchange to be included in the PBE0 functional from physical considerations based on the Koopman's condition. The challenges in correctly describing the fundamental energy gap of MOFs, without such a bias-free methodology, have been discussed by several authors. In fact, very often, the only experimental information that is provided is the optical gap that has a very different nature from the fundamental one, making it even harder to compare energy levels and experiments. Our method provides us with a direct determination of Fock exchange that allows us to compute the optical gap in striking agreement with the experimental one reported previously.

elements.content: The fact that we are able to obtain such a detailed molecular explanation of the optical and photo-excited state properties of this class of complex materials illustrates the remarkable progress that has been made in this field. In addition, we apply our theory to predict the lifetime of an electron hole of a novel material in the MIL-125 family and subsequent experiments nicely confirm our predictions.
elements.clean_text: The fact that we are able to obtain such a detailed molecular explanation of the optical and photo-excited state properties of this class of complex materials illustrates the remarkable progress that has been made in this field. In addition, we apply our theory to predict the lifetime of an electron hole of a novel material in the MIL-125 family and subsequent experiments nicely confirm our predictions.

elements.content: In this work, we employ an advanced theoretical framework, which enables us to unravel the underlying physical processes that are responsible for the different opto-electronic properties of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. We first calculate the fundamental and optical band gap of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 in striking agreement with the experiment. To achieve this goal, we employ density functional theory (DFT) and linear-response time-dependent DFT (LR-TDDFT) calculations based on a hybrid functional in which the fraction of Fock exchange is determined from physical considerations, in order to eliminate the noxious self-interaction error which affects the standard DFT. Then, by analyzing the nature of charge carriers in both materials, we observe that, upon excitation, the hole and the electron localize in spatially distinct regions of MIL-125-NH2, while they are largely overlapping in MIL-125. This explains the lower recombination rate experimentally measured for MIL-125-NH2. In addition, we estimate from LR-TDDFT calculations, the ratio of the recombination times for the two materials, obtaining an order of magnitude of difference, a value consistent with the measured lifetimes. These quantitative results are of particular importance as the method that we developed allows us to predict the effects of changes in the linker on the lifetime of the electron and the hole.

We first calculate the fundamental and optical band gap of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 in striking agreement with the experiment. To achieve this goal, we employ density functional theory (DFT) and linear-response time-dependent DFT (LR-TDDFT) calculations based on a hybrid functional in which the fraction of Fock exchange is determined from physical considerations, in order to eliminate the noxious self-interaction error which affects the standard DFT. Then, by analyzing the nature of charge carriers in both materials, we observe that, upon excitation, the hole and the electron localize in spatially distinct regions of MIL-125-NH2, while they are largely overlapping in MIL-125. This explains the lower recombination rate experimentally measured for MIL-125-NH2. In addition, we estimate from LR-TDDFT calculations, the ratio of the recombination times for the two materials, obtaining an order of magnitude of difference, a value consistent with the measured lifetimes. These quantitative results are of particular importance as the method that we developed allows us to predict the effects of changes in the linker on the lifetime of the electron and the hole.

elements.content: We calculate the electronic structure of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 using advanced PBE0-based hybrid functional calculations. To ensure that calculations of the frontier orbitals, or in band-structure terms, the top of the VB and the bottom of the CB, are not biased by the self-interaction error, we derive the amount of Fock exchange to be included in the PBE0 functional from physical considerations based on the Koopman’s condition. Following refs , , , we first inject an extra electron or an extra hole to MIL-125. Then, we relax the structures employing the PBE0 functional with a large fraction of Fock exchange (for more details, see the Supporting Information), observing charge localization in both cases. Next, we keep the achieved structures fixed and determine the fraction α for which the single particle energy level associated with the extra electron or extra hole does not vary upon occupation, as required by exact DFT. We obtain α = 0.36 for the electron polaron and α = 0.32 for the hole polaron (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, in the subsequent calculations, the average value α = 0.34 is used. More details can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Methodology and Energy Gap Calculation

We calculate the electronic structure of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 using advanced PBE0-based hybrid functional calculations. To ensure that calculations of the frontier orbitals, or in band-structure terms, the top of the VB and the bottom of the CB, are not biased by the self-interaction error, we derive the amount of Fock exchange to be included in the PBE0 functional from physical considerations based on the Koopman's condition. Following refs , , , we first inject an extra electron or an extra hole to MIL-125. Then, we relax the structures employing the PBE0 functional with a large fraction of Fock exchange (for more details, see the Supporting Information), observing charge localization in both cases. Next, we keep the achieved structures fixed and determine the fraction α for which the single particle energy level associated with the extra electron or extra hole does not vary upon occupation, as required by exact DFT. We obtain α = 0.36 for the electron polaron and α = 0.32 for the hole polaron (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, in the subsequent calculations, the average value α = 0.34 is used. More details can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: First, we analyze the electronic density of states at 0 K. The calculated projected density of states in shows that the lowest energy region of the CB of both MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 has a large contribution from the metal cluster formed by Ti­(3d) and O­(2p) atoms. The π orbitals of the bdc units form the highest energy peak of the VB of MIL-125. The presence of the amino group −NH2 introduces an additional band inside the gap, about 1.3 eV above the linker (π) band, as previously observed. In terms of crystalline orbitals, the highest occupied crystalline orbital (HOCO) is composed of the molecular π orbitals and the lowest unoccupied crystalline orbital (LUCO) is composed principally of the Ti­(3d) and O­(2p) orbitals (, top panel).

elements.content: The calculated fundamental band gap is 5.40 and 4.25 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. These values are drastically different from those recently reported. However, the available experiments are performed at room temperature and correspond to optical absorption measurements, while the calculations were performed at 0 K and they reported fundamental band gaps.
elements.clean_text: The calculated fundamental band gap is 5.40 and 4.25 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. These values are drastically different from those recently reported. However, the available experiments are performed at room temperature and correspond to optical absorption measurements, while the calculations were performed at 0 K and they reported fundamental band gaps.

elements.content: To make a comparison with the experiments, it is important to take into account the effect of temperature on the band gap. Following the previous work by Wiktor et al., we define the fundamental band gap at room temperature as E gap ( T ) = E g 0 + Δ T + Δ NQE where E g 0 is the fundamental energy gap at 0 K and ΔT, and ΔNQE are the band gap renormalizations induced by the thermal effect and the quantum motion of the nuclei, respectively. These terms are calculated by linear extrapolation of the density of states achieved from classical (ΔT) and path-integral molecular dynamics (MD) (ΔT + ΔNQE) simulations at room temperature (see the Supporting Information for more details). In , we illustrate the renormalization of the density of states of MIL-125 for both methods. The calculated renormalization is sizeable, amounting to 0.37 eV for the pure thermal effect and 0.75 eV for the thermal and quantum nuclei effects (). Because the two MOFs are very similar, we employ the calculated corrections of MIL-125 also for MIL-125-NH2. The resulting fundamental gap is 4.65 and 3.50 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively, which is still almost 1 eV larger than the measured values.

This difference is ascribed to the fact that experimental absorption spectra measure the optical band gap, while from the density of states, we obtain the fundamental one. The optical band gap is defined as the minimum energy needed to excite an electron from the top of the VB to the bottom of the CB. The optical band gap is smaller than the fundamental band gap because of the electrostatic interaction between the photogenerated charges (electrons and holes). The measured optical band gap is ca. 3.6 eV (345 nm) and 2.6 eV (475 nm) for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. We calculate the optical band gap using LR-TDDFT as implemented in the CP2K code. We find that the 0 K optical band gap is 4.44 and 3.36 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. As expected, the 0 K optical band gap is about 1 eV smaller than the 0 K fundamental band gap (), revealing a large excitonic effect, which is consistent with the low density of these materials and with their low dielectric constants (see calculations in the Supporting Information). By including the previously computed band gap renormalization, we finally obtain an optical band gap at room temperature of 3.69 and 2.61 eV for MIL-125 and its amino counterpart, in remarkable agreement with the measured optical band gaps ().

By including the previously computed band gap renormalization, we finally obtain an optical band gap at room temperature of 3.69 and 2.61 eV for MIL-125 and its amino counterpart, in remarkable agreement with the measured optical band gaps ().

elements.content: We next focus on the nature of the charge carriers in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. After illumination, an electron is photo-excited into the CB leaving a hole in the VB. elements.clean_text:
Interaction between Charge Carriers

We next focus on the nature of the charge carriers in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. After illumination, an electron is photo-excited into the CB leaving a hole in the VB. The two charges perturb the lattice, which undergoes a deformation in order to screen them. The resulting quasi-particles take the name of polarons. In addition, the negative (e-) and the positive (h+) polarons interact. We first study the polarons without interaction; we, separately, inject a hole and an electron in the MOFs and we relax the structure by using the same hybrid functional used in the electronic state calculation. We define the polaronic relaxation energy as the energy difference between the charged system (±) in its relaxed polaronic geometry (pol) and in the initial ground-state geometry (gs) 2       E   rel   ±   =   E   pol   ±   -   E   gs   ±

elements.content: reports the relaxation energies for the negative (E –) and the positive (E +) polarons for the two MOFs. The negative polaron relaxes by −0.34 and −0.50 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. As shown in a,b, the electron induces a distortion that breaks the crystal symmetry. As a result, the charge localizes in a section of the metal cluster. To further describe the observed polaronic states, we also evaluate the corresponding binding energies, employing a grand canonical formulation of defects in semiconductors (see the Supporting Information for details). The electron polaron is found 0.44 and 0.69 eV below the CB edge, in MIL and MIL-NH2, respectively. Because the CB edge for these materials is made up of the same states at almost equivalent energy, the electron polarons are found at very similar energies. For the hole, the relaxation energies are −0.04 and −0.19 eV for de-aminated and aminated MOFs, respectively. In both cases, the hole localizes into one of the linkers of the crystal, as shown in a,b. The higher stabilization in MIL-125-NH2 may be ascribed to the electron donor nature of the amino group. Hole polarons are found to occur as shallow states with binding energies of 0.08 and 0.15 eV, for MIL and MIL-NH2, respectively.

Subsequently, we study how the charge carriers interact. To this purpose, we consider the system in the triplet state. In fact, the triplet state corresponds to the lowest energy electronic configuration for the photo-excited electron/hole couple. As before, we calculate the relaxation energy by subtracting from the triplet state optimized geometry energy the ground-state geometry energy in the same spin state, here called E rel T. We then calculate the interaction energy, defined as E int = E rel T – (E rel + + E rel –). The results, as shown in , clearly indicate an attractive interaction (−0.04 eV) between the charge carrier in MIL-125; on the other hand, the interaction between the photo-electron and photohole is repulsive in MIL-125-NH2 (+0.46 eV). By observing the isodensity representation of the hole and electron wavefunction, as shown in c,d, we notice that in MIL-125, the two overlap significantly, while in MIL-125-NH2, they occupy two almost orthogonal regions of the crystal. In particular, the electron localizes onto the metal cluster and the hole on one of the linkers. A similar phenomenon has recently been observed in metal halide perovskites. This result suggests that the charge carrier interaction might be the key to determine the excited-state lifetime in this class of materials.

elements.content: To validate the hypothesis that charge carrier interactions determine the excited-state lifetime, we estimate the ratio between the radiative time decay of MIL-125-NH2 (τMIL‑125‑NH2 ) and MIL-125 (τMIL‑125). Recent transient absorption spectroscopy measurements reveal that τMIL‑125‑NH2 is at least 1 order of magnitude larger than τMIL‑125. The radiative time decay τ is equal to the inverse of the decay rate, k, τ = 1/k. From LR-TDDFT calculations, we obtain the oscillator strength f of the radiative transition from the excited states to the ground state, which is proportional to the radiative rate, f ∝ k(ν2)−1, where ν is the wavenumber of the transition. Following this, we can write the ratio as τ MIL ‐ 125 ‐ N H 2 τ MIL ‐ 125 = k MIL ‐ 125 k MIL ‐ 125 ‐ N H 2 = f MIL ‐ 125 f MIL ‐ 125 ‐ N H 2 ν MIL ‐ 125 ‐ N H 2 2 ν MIL ‐ 125 2

elements.content: Here, we call the electronic ground state, which is in a singlet state, S 0; the first singlet excited state is S 1 and the lowest triplet state is T 1. As previously described, the charge carrier pair relaxes, after photo-excitation, into T 1. We calculate, using LR-TDDFT, the oscillator strengths of the optical transitions at the relaxed T 1 geometry. Because the oscillator strength is proportional to the square of the dipole moment, it is independent of the direction of the transition, meaning that f T 1→S 0 = f S 0→T 1 . Calculation of the oscillator strength for singlet to triplet state transitions is not possible without including spin–orbit coupling (SOC). However, SOC correction is very similar in the two MOFs (the ratio between them is 1). In addition, we check that the spatial component of the wavefunction of S 1 and T 1 for these MOFs is the same, and thus, we can finally approximate f T 1 with f S 1 . A scheme of the possible optical transitions is shown in .

To test our charge carrier separation model on an unknown MIL-125 MOF, we studied a modified version of MIL-125-NH2 by substituting about 10% of the bdc-NH2 linker with bdc-(OH)2. Hydroxy groups, as amino groups, are strong π-activating substituents. This suggests that, like MIL-125-NH2, the corresponding bdc-(OH)2-modified MOF might have photocatalytic properties. To this purpose, we calculate the charge carrier relaxation and interaction energies (see ). Indeed, the charge carrier interaction energy is positive, 0.32 eV, indicating a repulsion between the photo-excited charges. Both negative and positive polaron relaxation energies are very similar to the ones observed in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. However, like for MIL-125-NH2, the charge carrier pair relaxation energy E rel T is quite small. As a consequence, the interaction energy is positive. Compared to MIL-125-NH2, the repulsion energy is 0.15 eV smaller suggesting a shorter lifetime of the excited state.
elements.clean_text:
Prediction

To test our charge carrier separation model on an unknown MIL-125 MOF, we studied a modified version of MIL-125-NH2 by substituting about 10% of the bdc-NH2 linker with bdc-(OH)2. Hydroxy groups, as amino groups, are strong π-activating substituents. This suggests that, like MIL-125-NH2, the corresponding bdc-(OH)2-modified MOF might have photocatalytic properties. To this purpose, we calculate the charge carrier relaxation and interaction energies (see ). Indeed, the charge carrier interaction energy is positive, 0.32 eV, indicating a repulsion between the photo-excited charges. Both negative and positive polaron relaxation energies are very similar to the ones observed in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. However, like for MIL-125-NH2, the charge carrier pair relaxation energy E rel T is quite small. As a consequence, the interaction energy is positive. Compared to MIL-125-NH2, the repulsion energy is 0.15 eV smaller suggesting a shorter lifetime of the excited state.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that we make this prediction for a material that has not yet been synthesized. To confirm these predictions, we synthesized MIL-125-NH2-[10%]­(OH)2 and we performed transient absorption spectroscopy for this material (see the Supporting Information for details on the synthesis and the measurements) and its pure amino counterpart MIL-125-NH2. The measurements, as reported in , show that indeed, the excited state of MIL-125-NH2-[10%]­(OH)2 decays faster than MIL-125-NH2, nicely confirming the predictions of our computational model. We fitted the decay curves with a double exponential function. The fast components, accounting for the first 1 μs, as shown in the inset of , are 523 ± 11 and 297 ± 15 ns for MIL-125-NH2 and MIL-125-NH2-[10%]­(OH)2, respectively.

elements.content: In this work, we analyzed the electronic structure of two MOFs, MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, before and after photo-excitation. Experimental measurements have shown that MIL-125-NH2 can be used as an antenna in photocatalytic systems. In such a system, the MOF captures the light and creates an electron and a hole; the electron is subsequently transported to a cocatalyst where, for example, a water splitting reaction takes place (see for example ref and references therein). If we use MIL-125, on the other hand, no catalytic activity is observed. We first calculated the fundamental and optical energy gap, at 0 K and room temperature, employing an advanced theoretical framework based on a physical consideration. We found that the calculated optical gap is in striking agreement with the experimental one. Then, we analyzed the relaxation of the photogenerated electron/hole pair. We observed two opposite behaviors in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. Although in the former there is an attraction of the electron and hole pair, in MIL-125-NH2, the interaction energy of the charge carriers is positive. The attraction/repulsion of the electron/hole pair has consequences for the radiative decay time. In fact, the radiative decay time depends on the recombination rate of the charge carriers. Charge carriers that attract each other tend to occupy the same spatial region in the crystal, increasing the probability of recombination, and vice-versa, distant charge carriers are less likely to recombine. Finally, by using LR-TDDFT, we have shown that indeed, the recombination rate in MIL-125-NH2 is about 1 order of magnitude larger than in MIL-125, as previously observed in transient absorption measurements. In addition, we correctly predict a shorter lifetime for MIL-125-NH2-[10%]­(OH)2 than for MIL-125-NH2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we analyzed the electronic structure of two MOFs, MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, before and after photo-excitation. Experimental measurements have shown that MIL-125-NH2 can be used as an antenna in photocatalytic systems. In such a system, the MOF captures the light and creates an electron and a hole; the electron is subsequently transported to a cocatalyst where, for example, a water splitting reaction takes place (see for example ref  and references therein). If we use MIL-125, on the other hand, no catalytic activity is observed. We first calculated the fundamental and optical energy gap, at 0 K and room temperature, employing an advanced theoretical framework based on a physical consideration. We found that the calculated optical gap is in striking agreement with the experimental one. Then, we analyzed the relaxation of the photogenerated electron/hole pair. We observed two opposite behaviors in MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. Although in the former there is an attraction of the electron and hole pair, in MIL-125-NH2, the interaction energy of the charge carriers is positive. The attraction/repulsion of the electron/hole pair has consequences for the radiative decay time. In fact, the radiative decay time depends on the recombination rate of the charge carriers. Charge carriers that attract each other tend to occupy the same spatial region in the crystal, increasing the probability of recombination, and vice-versa, distant charge carriers are less likely to recombine. Finally, by using LR-TDDFT, we have shown that indeed, the recombination rate in MIL-125-NH2 is about 1 order of magnitude larger than in MIL-125, as previously observed in transient absorption measurements. In addition, we correctly predict a shorter lifetime for MIL-125-NH2-[10%](OH)2 than for MIL-125-NH2.

This difference is ascribed to the fact that experimental absorption spectra measure the optical band gap, while from the density of states, we obtain the fundamental one. The optical band gap is defined as the minimum energy needed to excite an electron from the top of the VB to the bottom of the CB. The optical band gap is smaller than the fundamental band gap because of the electrostatic interaction between the photogenerated charges (electrons and holes). The measured optical band gap is ca. 3.6 eV (345 nm) and 2.6 eV (475 nm) for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. We calculate the optical band gap using LR-TDDFT as implemented in the CP2K code. We find that the 0 K optical band gap is 4.44 and 3.36 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. As expected, the 0 K optical band gap is about 1 eV smaller than the 0 K fundamental band gap (), revealing a large excitonic effect, which is consistent with the low density of these materials and with their low dielectric constants (see calculations in the Supporting Information). By including the previously computed band gap renormalization, we finally obtain an optical band gap at room temperature of 3.69 and 2.61 eV for MIL-125 and its amino counterpart, in remarkable agreement with the measured optical band gaps ().

As expected, the 0 K optical band gap is about 1 eV smaller than the 0 K fundamental band gap (), revealing a large excitonic effect, which is consistent with the low density of these materials and with their low dielectric constants (see calculations in the Supporting Information). By including the previously computed band gap renormalization, we finally obtain an optical band gap at room temperature of 3.69 and 2.61 eV for MIL-125 and its amino counterpart, in remarkable agreement with the measured optical band gaps ().

  reports the relaxation energies for the negative (E -) and the positive (E +) polarons for the two MOFs. The negative polaron relaxes by -0.34 and -0.50 eV for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, respectively. As shown in a,b, the electron induces a distortion that breaks the crystal symmetry. As a result, the charge localizes in a section of the metal cluster. To further describe the observed polaronic states, we also evaluate the corresponding binding energies, employing a grand canonical formulation of defects in semiconductors (see the Supporting Information for details). The electron polaron is found 0.44 and 0.69 eV below the CB edge, in MIL and MIL-NH2, respectively. Because the CB edge for these materials is made up of the same states at almost equivalent energy, the electron polarons are found at very similar energies. For the hole, the relaxation energies are -0.04 and -0.19 eV for de-aminated and aminated MOFs, respectively. In both cases, the hole localizes into one of the linkers of the crystal, as shown in a,b. The higher stabilization in MIL-125-NH2 may be ascribed to the electron donor nature of the amino group. Hole polarons are found to occur as shallow states with binding energies of 0.08 and 0.15 eV, for MIL and MIL-NH2, respectively.

It is interesting to note that we make this prediction for a material that has not yet been synthesized. To confirm these predictions, we synthesized MIL-125-NH2-[10%](OH)2 and we performed transient absorption spectroscopy for this material (see the Supporting Information for details on the synthesis and the measurements) and its pure amino counterpart MIL-125-NH2. The measurements, as reported in , show that indeed, the excited state of MIL-125-NH2-[10%](OH)2 decays faster than MIL-125-NH2, nicely confirming the predictions of our computational model. We fitted the decay curves with a double exponential function. The fast components, accounting for the first 1 μs, as shown in the inset of , are 523 ± 11 and 297 ± 15 ns for MIL-125-NH2 and MIL-125-NH2-[10%](OH)2, respectively.
